metadata.name: kylt #90
metadata.description:
Dissolving, dancing, decaying structures.

Using tinycolor2 and p5-noise.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Glossolalia #200
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverse… which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, it’s about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. It’s less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append “&density=2” to the url to double the size, “&density=3” to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append “&grain=##” to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: Cellular Skyscrapers #149
metadata.description:
A "Cellular Skyscraper" originates from a 15x15 grid with 15x3 cells randomly assigned the 'alive' state. According to the cellular automaton rule chosen from the transaction hash 24 new generations are calculated and placed on top of each other.

There are four different rules available (listed in Golly notation) all based on the Moore neighbourhood: 

B3/S23 (Game of Life)
B36/S125 (2x2)
B368/S245 (Morley)
B3/S234 (didn't find a name for it but produces interesting large structures)

After all generations have been calculated the algorithm searches through the complete 3D grid to find the one structure consisting of the most connected alive cells - cells are connected when they have at least one alive neighbour in any of the three axis.

Features are cell count, height, highlight color, ca rule and antenna count.

Extra: press 'd' to download the structure as a .gltf file to import into Blender or other software.
 
Enjoy!

metadata.name: Wandering Line #159
metadata.description:
An agent moves free around a limited 3dimensional space.
It starts drawing a line that changes its color based on a generative process inspired by 6 paintings of Palazuelo (Spanish painter).
The 3d line get then projected on a random plane and converted into a 2d drawing. Keeping perspective and depth.

This is an attempt to create geometrical drawings that are clearly made by a computer but that resembles a hand drawn / sketched painting.

Press "s" or "S" to get a screenshot.

The parameter digital mood is just how the code feels at the time of minting.

Original piece by Ismahelio. Made with p5js. Madrid, 2021.
The digital mood parameter

metadata.name: Sugar & Splice #379
metadata.description:
'Sugar & Splice'

Vibrant somethings, full of flavor, dancing within conjoined boundaries.

Controls:
s: Saves an image of the canvas with the current settings
1-6: Scales the canvas size, from 1 (default, 2048px x 2792px) to 6 (12288px x  16752px)
g: Toggles grain texture
t: Toggles background transparency
f: Toggles fit to screen (layout and other factors will change based on the new size, but overall style, colors, etc will remain the same)
p: Shortcut for large print settings: disables the grain texture and scales the canvas to the largest setting
b: Toggles b-side 

teaboswell 2022
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: Tessera #25
metadata.description:
Tessera is a project inspired by historical Mosaics. A tessera (Latin) is a small individual tile, usually formed in the shape of a square, used for making a mosaic. As the world's first "pixel art", Tessera is a tribute to this craft. This collection is made solely of rectangles on a two-dimensional canvas into an abstract mosaic flow with a three-dimensional effect.

Press s in live mode to download.

Download a higher resolution by adding to the URL:
&density=2 / &density=3 / &density=4

Lammetje Oktober 2022

metadata.name: Polar Grid #608
metadata.description:
Polar Grid is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

This is a study of color, motion, and composition, and an homage to cinema as an artform. Colorful shapes overlap and pulse in a ever repeating dance. An abstracted movie experience. Each color palette in the series (except one) is inspired by a different film director (if you want a real challenge, see how many you can guess without looking at the feature names).

The palettes were extracted from movie stills or movie posters and fine tuned by hand. As often, I have to thank independent tool makers for their indirect help. My gratitude goes to David Aerne for FarbVélo and Fabrizio Bianchi for Coolors.

The code for Polar Grid is based on early iterations of what ultimately became my carat series. Both projects come from the same fascination for color as a system, even though I used a different approach here. You could call this a carat prequel.

The animation is done using a technique called polar noise. This makes it so the motion of all elements ends up repeating in the same amount of time. This is useful for generating motion that loops perfectly while still appearing organic. In this particular case, the animation repeats every π × 100 seconds.

A challenge in building any generative system is to find the right balance between coherence and variety. I designed the system with the large edition size in mind. During development I generated hundreds of iterations and tweaked my code to make sure that every iteration is truly unique and fits the overall aesthetic of the collection.

I truly hope you will enjoy your own little abstract movie.

— Raphaël de Courville


Released: July 6th 2022

Medium: p5.js, html canvas, css

Reference: sk220621


**About the artist**

Raphaël de Courville is a generative artist, streamer, and educator. His artistic work is an exploration of generative systems, patterns, interactivity, and time. Born in Paris, he lives and works in Berlin.


**Instructions**

- Click/Tap or press SPACEBAR to play and pause the animation

In Fullscreen mode (desktop only):
- Press UP or DOWN arrows to adjust image quality (Note: this can affect performance)
- Press F to hide/show the browser UI

metadata.name: A Burroughs Quote #171
metadata.description:
A Burroughs Quote is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022

The birth of the Cut Up Method via the third mind. Dream Machine. Fragments. Morocco. It takes one to know one.

Esoteric rarity. Value is intended to be determined by viewer aesthetic alone.

Chrome or Firefox is recommended for your maximum viewing pleasure.

This artwork was created using p5js.

lisaorth.xyz
linktr.ee/lisaorthstudio
twitter: @lisaorthstudio

metadata.name: ____ - Iteration 3 #46
metadata.description:
This project is part of a larger experiment that explores and celebrates the process of making generative art by progressively releasing iterations, working towards a final release on my main account (tz1RkYY3jr1ocuPdQqrRefr5FqoawKQsmBmD). The iterations will be titled ____ - Iteration 1, ____ - Iteration 2, etc. At this point, the number of iterations has not been determined, but more information will be provided as this experiment unfolds.

The final release will only be made available to those who have collected each iteration (using an allowlist), and will be released for free.

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

metadata.name: CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE #627
metadata.description:
1 of 5 in CENTURY-XXX, Series 2
Edition of 1000

Tribute to Herbert W. Franke
“In Honor of the Dinosaur of Computer Art” 

Herbert W. Franke, a pioneer of computer art, passed away on July 16, 2022 at the age of 95. CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE is an homage to Franke’s MONDRIAN software developed for the Texas Instruments TI 99/4 home computer in 1979, and it’s a fundraiser to digitize his archive:

“Our goal is to raise 20,000 Euro so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Franke’s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. If we raise more money, it will be donated to the Rütgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.” 

Each frame, a single “pixel” is added to the CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE image. When the software first loads, 100,000 frames are run in the background to start things off. Keep it running for hours or days to see it transform entirely — it’s an “infinite animation.”

metadata.name: Little Trees #133
metadata.description:
Delicate, little trees. Some with green leaves, some with orange, some with red. This is the genesis project of Brian Gawlik.

The default resolution is 3600x3600. To redraw and save as an image at a different resolution - in the live view, open your browser's devtools and execute the function saveImg(pixWidth) where pixWidth is the desired width in pixels of the image. For example, saveImg(4096) will prompt you to download a 4096x4096 image. It is recommended not to export below 2400x2400 as this will compromise the aesthetic of the shadow.

metadata.name: Still Life #201
metadata.description:
is this the real life? is this just f(x)antasy?

made entirely in p5js

metadata.name: ____ - Iteration 1 #391
metadata.description:
This project is part of a larger experiment that explores and celebrates the process of making generative art by progressively releasing iterations, working towards a final release on my main account (tz1RkYY3jr1ocuPdQqrRefr5FqoawKQsmBmD). The iterations will be titled ____ 0.1, ____ 0.2, etc. At this point, the number of iterations has not been determined, but more information will be provided as this experiment unfolds.

The final release will only be made available to those who have collected each iteration (using an allowlist), and will be released for free.

metadata.name: Retroscapes #12
metadata.description:
You are approaching newly discovered planetary ring system, seen by no human before.
Gravity works in strange ways there. Intrigued, you grab your polaroid. 
Snap, and there it is - your grainy Retroscape.

Beauty comes from diversity.

Size of the collection - 222 pieces - is a tribute to my first NFT.

metadata.name: Shape of 2 #129
metadata.description:
My second minimalist generative token is about a ’Shape of 2’. 
2 vertical sets of fine lines create ONE sculpture. The left versus the right side can be either mirrored, show similar or even oppositional expressions - depending on the generated length of the horizontal lines. A ’Shape of 2’ might remind one of a classic vase, a river or a sculpture - depending on its body language.

metadata.name: Particulate Hash #34
metadata.description:
Move, spin, and drift. Particulate matter.
Click + drag to affect the particles

metadata.name: Weave #311
metadata.description: Generative artwork made with p5.js

metadata.name: Windswept #169
metadata.description:
Windswept

Press 's' in live view to download a copy of your image.

You can add the URL parameter 'scale' to scale the size of the image for a higher resolution download (1600x2000 by default). For example, for a 3200x4000 image, add '&scale=2' to the end of the URL. 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are valid inputs. (Warning: large numbers may not work depending on your hardware/browser and can produce a very large download file of ~100mb)

teaboswell, 2022
License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0
For third party license information, please see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt

metadata.name: Miniscapes #264
metadata.description:
Miniscapes merges generative code (Rich's bit) with meticulously designed scenes and elements (Rick's bit), to create minimalist landscapes intended to charm, delight, and surprise.

Our aim was to convey as much as possible with as little as possible by using simple shapes and lines to represent a wide variety of natural landscapes.

We hope that you find as much joy in owning a Miniscape as we did in creating them.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save the current image
- Press [p] to pause an animated output
- Press [r] to reset an animated output (this will also pause)
